g.text: Diagenetic alteration of the elemental and isotopic elements in ancient carbonates
and mudstones can obliterate primary depositional trends and therefore these require an adequate assessment.
The Mn/Sr ratio has been regarded as a sensitive indicator of diagenetic alteration in carbonates
suggested that samples with values as high as 10 still produced reliable carbon isotope signatures
Sr ratio yields values of 0.61â€“6.48 in this study (Supplementary TableÂ S5) and most of them were
suggest these samples were nearly unaltered, so they preserve primary depositional characteristics. Moreover,
the carbon and oxygen isotope cross-plot (Supplementary Fig.Â S3) shows no obvious positive linear relationship
C values, and data points are relatively discrete, indicating that these elements are basically
not affected by diagenesis, and the resulting isotope data are reliable
gen isotopes may have undergone strong diagenesis when the sample
are less susceptible to diagenesis than oxygen isotopes
and in some cases where the formation of a diagenetic

. The Ti/Al ratio is a useful indicator in discrimination of source area
differences and has been applied to rocks spanning from the Precambrian through to the Cenozoic
study, the value of most Ti/Al ratios is 0.4â€“0.6 (Supplementary TableÂ S5) except for a few abnormal data, and the
relatively stable Ti/Al ratio suggests an unchanging source area for the sediments comprising the Sunjiagou and

show consistent negative excursions at the fossil assemblage zone and the PTB interval. Sensitive proxies
increase at the fossil spots and the PTB interval. Values of (K
indicate a relatively low palaeotemperature at the fossil spots and the PTB interval. Mg/Ca, Sr/Ca and Ba/Ca
) consistently show negative excursions at the fossil assemblage zone and the PTB interval while Sc/Zr and
show strong negative excursions at these points.
Palaeontological and geochemical evidence demonstrate that the PTB in the Shanxi red beds is at a horizon
about 15 m below the top of Sunjiagou Formation (FigsÂ
), and the detrital zicon ages from the Sunjiagou
and Liujiagou formations support this scenario (Supplementary TableÂ S6). The synchronous dramatic negative
O in the uppermost Sunjiagou Formation provide reliable evidence for reduced weath-
Aeolian dune and wind ripple deposits overlying a sand-drift surface on fluvial sandstones within the
Liujiagou Formation. The white arrow points to the aeolian pin stripe lamination. Abbreviations: SD, sand-drift
surface; PL, planebed lamination; ICR, inverse climbing-ripple; GFL, grainfall lamination. Photo credit: Y.Q.L.
